Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story: I stood in the crowded polling station, clutching my ID, my heart pounding. My mother’s words echoed in my mind: “We always vote together, and we never sign anything we don’t fully understand. That’s our way.” Just last night, my family gathered around the dinner table, reminding me how important it was to honor our traditions—never rush, never compromise our values, always double-check everything. But now, the election official was explaining, her voice urgent, that my registration didn’t match. If I wanted my vote to count, I had to fill out a provisional ballot form—right now, before the station closed in ten minutes. She handed me the form, her eyes expectant. I could feel the weight of my family’s expectations pressing down on me, warning me not to act hastily. Yet, as a voter, I was supposed to follow the official’s instructions and make sure my voice was heard. My hands trembled as I stared at the form, torn between the duty to my family’s traditions and the responsibility to participate in the election.
